choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve involved in this test: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

SPECIAL TESTS FOR MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign / Ochsner’s Clasping / Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. Special tests for ulnar nerve injury are:

 

  • Froment’s sign:
    • Test: The patient is asked to make a strong pinch between the thumb and index finger and grip a flat object such as a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. The examiner then attempts to pull the object out of the patient’s hands.
    • Interpretation: There is weakness of the adductor pollicis innervated by the ulnar nerve which would keep the IP joint relatively straight; instead, the FPL muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve is substituted for the AP and will cause the IP joint to go into a hyperflexed position.

 

 

  • Wartenberg’s sign:
    • Test: The patient’s places wrist in neutral and forearm in full pronation and is instructed to perform full extension of all the fingers. Once digits are extended, patient is asked to fully abduct and then adduct all fingers.
    • Interpretation: A positive sign is indicated with the observation of abduction of the 5th digit, with the inability to adduct the 5th finger when extended.

 

 

  • Egawa’s sign:
    • Test: The patient flexes the middle digit & then alternately deviates the finger radially & ulnarly.
    • Interpretation: If the patient is unable to do this Egawa’s sign, the interossei are affected.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Check strength of Biceps Brachii, Corocobrachialis and Brachialis muscles. Check sensation on lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The test image shown in the question is the Pen Test, which is done to diagnose median nerve injury.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with a 10-year history of coarse facial features and progressive enlargement of the hands and feet. Laboratory evaluation revealed elevated IGF-1 and non-suppressible growth hormone levels after the 75 g glucose challenge test. A diagnosis of acromegaly is made. Which of the following drugs is preferred for the management of this condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lanreotide depot formulation

 

Acromegaly is a condition caused by excess growth hormone, often due to a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. The clinical features include coarse facial features and enlargement of the hands and feet. The diagnosis is confirmed with elevated IGF-1 levels and non-suppressible growth hormone levels following a glucose challenge test.

 

The first-line treatment for a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma is transsphenoidal surgery. However, when surgery is not immediately possible or has failed, medical management is necessary.

 

The preferred drugs in these situations are somatostatin receptor agonists, such as lanreotide, octreotide, and pasireotide. Lanreotide depot formulation is effective in reducing growth hormone levels and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Terlipressin: Incorrect. Terlipressin is primarily used in the management of acute variceal bleeding related to liver conditions, not in the treatment of acromegaly.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Incorrect. Ketoconazole is used in managing Cushing's syndrome in children due to its ability to inhibit cortisol synthesis. It is not indicated for the treatment of acromegaly.

 

Option D. Leuprolide: Incorrect. Leuprolide is a GnRH analogue used in the management of gynecological conditions such as fibroids and in prostate cancer. It is not effective in treating acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred medical management for acromegaly, especially as a bridge to surgery or when surgery has failed, is the use of somatostatin receptor agonists like lanreotide depot formulation.

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

Generalized symptoms of fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis along with chest x-ray showing multiple cavitation lesions are suggestive of tuberculosis. This diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • Chest X-ray: Presence of multiple cavitary lesions, which are characteristic of pulmonary TB.
  • Biopsy Findings: The presence of granulomas, multinucleated giant cells (Langhans type), and caseous necrosis is indicative of TB, which involves granulomatous inflammation with a distinctive type of necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's Granulomatosis: This could also present with nasal deformity and granulomas but is usually associated with vasculitis and lacks the caseous necrosis typical of TB.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Can cause nasal collapse ("saddle nose") but typically does not present with the lung involvement seen in TB.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Also presents with granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis seen in TB and typically shows non-cavitary lung lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis should be considered in patients presenting with respiratory symptoms, systemic signs, and nasal deformities when accompanied by histological evidence of caseating granulomas. This constellation of findings is distinct in suggesting TB over other granulomatous diseases.

 

Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:

questions.text: An adult male is presented with duodenal ulcer is offered various surgical options for its treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below causes least side effects with good healing of ulcers?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Highly selective vagotomy
 

Duodenal ulcers can be caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, increased acid secretion, or the use of NSAIDs. When medical management is ineffective or complications arise, surgical treatment may be necessary. Among the surgical options, a highly selective vagotomy (HSV) is preferred due to its ability to effectively reduce acid secretion while causing the least side effects and offering good ulcer healing.

  • This procedure, also known as parietal cell vagotomy or proximal gastric vagotomy, targets only the vagal nerve fibers that stimulate acid-producing parietal cells in the stomach. It spares the vagal innervation to the antrum, pylorus, and the remaining abdominal viscera.
  • By preserving the innervation to the antrum and pylorus, HSV maintains more normal gastric function, reducing the risk of side effects such as delayed gastric emptying and diarrhea.
  • This makes it the surgical option with the least side effects and a good rate of ulcer healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Truncal Vagotomy:

 

  • Involves dividing the main trunk of the vagus nerve as it enters the abdomen, significantly reducing parasympathetic stimulation to the stomach and decreasing gastric acid secretion.
  • Although effective in reducing acid secretion, it often causes significant side effects, including delayed gastric emptying and diarrhea, due to the loss of vagal control over the entire stomach and other abdominal organs.

 

Option B. Selective Vagotomy:

 

  • Selectively cuts the vagus nerve fibers supplying the stomach while preserving the nerve supply to the pylorus, liver, and biliary system.
  • Reduces acid secretion less than truncal vagotomy but preserves more normal stomach function. However, it is still associated with more side effects compared to highly selective vagotomy.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy:

 

  • Creates a new connection between the stomach and the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum where the ulcer is located.
  • Does not reduce acid secretion and does not address the underlying cause of the ulcer. It is typically performed for ulcer complications or in combination with other procedures. It may be associated with dumping syndrome and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highly selective vagotomy (HSV) is the preferred surgical option for chronic duodenal ulcers due to its effective reduction of acid secretion, minimal side effects, and good ulcer healing rate.

questions.text: Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-C

 

Explanation:

 

  • MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser): This syndrome has a karyotype of 46XX.
  • Swyer Syndrome: This condition is characterized by 46XY karyotype.
  • Turner Syndrome: This is due to monosomy X, having a karyotype of 45XO.
  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: This condition occurs in individuals with a karyotype of 46XY, where there is a complete androgen insensitivity, resulting in a phenotypically female appearance despite having male (XY) chromosomes.

 

Matching:

 

  1. MRKH: 46XX
  2. Swyer Syndrome: 46XY
  3. Turner Syndrome: 45XO
  4. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the karyotypes associated with different syndromes helps in diagnosing and managing these conditions effectively. MRKH is associated with 46XX, Swyer syndrome with 46XY, Turner syndrome with 45XO, and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome with 46XY.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 446,447

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

questions.text: The latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period of a skeletal muscle are 10 ms, 40 ms, and 50 ms respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 25 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as - 1/contraction period.

 

In this problem, contraction period is 40msec = 0.04sec

 

So, Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanization-  As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called Tetanization.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The next best step in management in this patient is steroid irrigation and antihistamines.

 

This patient who had previously undergone FESS 5 years ago for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis.

 

Acute rhinosinusitis usually develops along with viral upper respiratory tract infection due to mucosal swelling causing obstruction of the sinus ostia. Persistent or worsening symptoms even after 10 days with fever and purulent discharge indicates secondary bacterial infection.

 

Treatment initially is symptomatic with -

 

  • First line of treatment - Nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines
  • In cases of secondary bacterial infection antibiotics are indicated. Amoxyclav is the drug of choice.
  • Biological therapy is not used in the treatment of sinusitis. It may be used in cases of refractory polyp.
  • Revision surgery is indicated only when maximal medical therapy has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat Surgery: Indicated only if there are anatomical obstructions or complications that cannot be managed medically. In this case, the DNE shows patent ostia, so repeat surgery is not indicated without further evidence of structural issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Could be considered for their anti-inflammatory properties in some chronic rhinosinusitis cases, but there is no mention of bacterial infection needing long-term antibiotics, making this less suitable than symptomatic management.

 

Option D. Biological Therapy: Mainly used for refractory cases with specific underlying conditions such as severe asthma or nasal polyps, which is not indicated here based on the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 213, 214

questions.text: Which joint allows for the side-to-side movement of the head, enabling a person to look to the right and left?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atlanto-axial

 

  • The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.
  • The atlanto-axial joints consist of two lateral joints located on either side between the bottom of the atlas bone and the top of the axis bone, which are flat joints.
  • Additionally, there is a central joint between the dens (a protrusion from the axis bone) and the front arch and transverse ligament of the atlas, which is a pivot joint.
  • This central joint has two distinct synovial cavities - one in the front and one in the back.
  • Rotatory movements occur at all three joints and revolve around a vertical axis.
  • The dens acts as a pivot around which the atlas rotates (carrying the skull with it), allowing the head to rotate side to side.
  • The alar ligaments restrict movement. Atlanto-axial rotation has a normal range of about 40°.

 

Atlanto-Axial joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atlanto-occipital joint: This joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the occipital bone of the skull. It primarily permits the "nodding" motion of the head, as in signaling "yes". This joint allows for flexion and extension of the head, but not significant rotation. It's the joint that lets you tilt your head upward or downward.

 

Option C. C2-C3 joint: This joint is between the second and third cervical vertebrae. While it does allow for some degree of rotation, it does not provide the primary rotational movement to look right or left. The range of motion at this joint is less compared to the atlanto-axial joint, and it's more involved in flexion, extension, and some lateral bending.

 

Option D. C3-C4 joint: This joint is between the third and fourth cervical vertebrae. Like the C2-C3 joint, the C3-C4 joint also provides some degree of rotation but not the primary movement. Its main movements are flexion, extension, and lateral bending of the neck. The lower down the cervical spine you go, the less rotational capacity there typically is at each subsequent joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atlanto-axial joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the second cervical vertebra (the axis or C2). The dens or odontoid process, fits into the atlas, allowing for a pivot-like rotation. This is the joint responsible for allowing the rotation of the head from side to side, as in signaling "no" or looking right and left. It provides the majority of the rotational capability of the head.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with left facial weakness. Routine lab workup was normal. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The presentation of left facial weakness with normal routine lab workup suggests Bell's palsy, an idiopathic condition characterized by sudden onset of unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion and is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis.

 

Corticosteroids: The first-line treatment for Bell's palsy is corticosteroids. They are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. Early treatment with corticosteroids can significantly improve the chances of complete recovery. A typical regimen is prednisolone or prednisone.

 

Dosage: Prednisone 60-80 mg per day for 5-7 days, followed by a taper over the next 5-7 days.

 

Note – In the severity grading system, House-Brackmann grading, if the patient has Grade 4 or Grade 5 severity, consider adding antivirals such as acyclovir or valacyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Although acyclovir or other antiviral agents like valacyclovir are sometimes used, their benefit is less clear. They may be considered in severe cases of Bell's palsy, particularly when there is a suspicion of herpes simplex virus involvement, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Dosage: Valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days or acyclovir 400 mg five times a day for 7-10 days.

 

Note - Valacyclovir has superior bioavailability, superior efficacy, and lower side effects compared to acyclovir.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: There is no role for antibiotics in the treatment of Bell's palsy as it is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Physiotherapy: While physiotherapy, including facial exercises and eye protection measures, can be supportive, it is not the primary treatment and should be considered an adjunct to corticosteroid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best initial management for a patient with Bell's palsy is corticosteroid therapy. Early administration within 72 hours of symptom onset greatly enhances the likelihood of complete recovery. Antivirals may be added in severe cases, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient died, and his body was brought for post-mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rokitansky technique

 

Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

 

 

Rokitansky Method

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

 

Ghon’s Method

 

Option B. Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

       

Letulle’s Method

 

Option C. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

 

Virchow’s Method

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rokitansky technique involves dissecting organs in situ and is the preferred method for highly infectious diseases like HIV to prevent the spread of infection.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in ABCD2 scoring? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) History of stroke

 

Explanation:

 

The ABCD2 score is used to assess the risk of developing a subsequent stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

 

The components of the ABCD2 score include:

 

  • A (Age): Age 60 years or older scores 1 point.
  • B (Blood Pressure): Systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or higher, or diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg or higher scores 1 point.
  • C (Clinical Features): Unilateral weakness scores 2 points; speech disturbance without weakness scores 1 point.
  • D (Diabetes): Presence of diabetes scores 1 point.
  • D (Duration of Symptoms): Symptoms lasting 60 minutes or longer score 2 points; symptoms lasting 10-59 minutes score 1 point.

 

History of stroke is not included in the ABCD2 scoring system. Instead, it is a component of other scoring systems, such as the CHADS2 or CHA2DS2-VASc scores, which are used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and to guide anticoagulation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age: Age 60 years or older is a factor in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: The presence of diabetes is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ABCD2 score includes age, blood pressure, clinical features, duration of symptoms, and diabetes. History of stroke is not included in this scoring system but is part of other risk assessment tools like CHADS2 and CHA2DS2-VASc

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and white line of Frenkel on X-ray? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Vitamin C is crucial for the absorption of iron in the body as it converts ferric ion (Fe³⁺) to ferrous ion (Fe²⁺), the form in which iron is best absorbed in the intestine. A deficiency of vitamin C can impair iron absorption, leading to iron deficiency anemia. Additionally, vitamin C is essential for the post-translational modification of collagen, where proline is converted to hydroxyproline and lysine to hydroxylysine. This modification strengthens collagen fibers; without sufficient vitamin C, collagen becomes weak, leading to symptoms such as bleeding gums due to fragile blood vessels. The white line of Frenkel on X-ray is another characteristic sign of scurvy, a condition resulting from severe vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia (low neutrophil count), and hypopigmentation, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the specific X-ray findings mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron deficiency leads to anemia, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the white line of Frenkel on X-ray, which are specific to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Zinc: Zinc deficiency is associated with delayed wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, and immune dysfunction, but it does not cause the symptoms outlined in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and the white line of Frenkel on X-ray due to impaired iron absorption and defective collagen synthesis.

choices.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Isolate for 6 days

 

The given scenario points to the diagnosis of chickenpox.

 

In a boys' hostel, everyone is not in the high-risk groups for severe varicella infection. For the management of suspected cases in this situation, isolation for 6 days from the onset of the rash is the appropriate measure to prevent further spread of the infection. Acyclovir and ZIG are not necessary for healthy individuals.

 

Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is indicated as prophylaxis for individuals at high risk like Immunocompromised individuals, Pregnant women and Newborns.

 

 

 

Note –

 

Acyclovir: Antiviral treatment with acyclovir is generally reserved for high-risk groups or severe cases.

 

VZIG (Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin): VZIG is indicated for individuals at high risk of severe varicella infection, such as immunocompromised individuals, pregnant women, and newborns. It is not routinely given to healthy individuals in a setting like a boys' hostel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For managing a chickenpox outbreak in a boys' hostel, the best step is to isolate affected individuals for 6 days from the onset of the rash. This helps prevent the spread of the virus. Antiviral treatments and immunoglobulins are reserved for high-risk individuals.

choices.text: EMLA means equal mixture of LA
Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream
1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream 

 

The cream shown in the image is EMLA cream, which is a topical anesthetic. EMLA cream contains a combination of two local anesthetics, lidocaine and prilocaine, in a 1:1 ratio. One of the known complications of EMLA cream is methemoglobinemia. This condition can occur, especially when the cream is used in large quantities or in patients with certain predispositions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMLA means equal mixture of LA: EMLA means Eutectic mixture of LA and not equal mixture of LA.

 

Option B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine: This option is incorrect because EMLA cream does not contain ropivacaine. The active ingredients in EMLA cream are lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine.

 

Option D. 1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg: This option is also incorrect. 1 gram of EMLA 5% cream contains 25mg of lidocaine and 25mg of prilocaine, not 50mg of lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EMLA cream can cause methemoglobinemia as a complication, especially when used inappropriately or in large quantities.

choices.text: Asphyxia
Vagal inhibition
Laryngospasm
Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An Autopsy was conducted on a male with history of drowning. However, no water was found in his lungs, and he was determined to have experienced ‘dry drowning’. What is the cause of death: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laryngospasm

 

Option C. Laryngospasm : In cases of dry drowning, laryngospasm is a reflex closure of the vocal cords and other airway muscles that occurs when water touches the vocal cords or throat. This spasm can seal the airway, preventing water from entering the lungs but also air, leading to suffocation.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asphyxia : In typical drowning cases, this happens when water fills the lungs, preventing oxygen from reaching the blood. However, it isn't the direct cause in dry drowning.

 

Option B. Vagal Inhibition : This refers to a sudden stop of the heart due to a reflex action stimulated by extreme stress or shock, particularly cold water impacting the face. It can instantly stop heart activity but is rare.

 

Option D. Ventricular Fibrillation : Ventricular fibrillation is a severe cardiac rhythm disturbance where the heart's electrical activity becomes so chaotic that the heart stops pumping effectively, leading to sudden cardiac death. It can happen due to severe hypoxia from drowning.

 

Educational objective:

 

Dry drowning is characterized by a laryngospasm that prevents water from entering the lungs but leads to death through asphyxia due to a blocked airway.

questions.text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PDA

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASD: ASD is the common congenital heart disease in down syndrome

 

Option B. VSD: VSD is the common congenital heart disease in infant of diabetic mother

 

Option D. PS: PS (pulmonary stenosis) is the common congenital heart disease in noonan and Alagille syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), followed by Pulmonary Stenosis (PS).

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. 
  • It is well known to cause gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, particularly when first starting the medication or when the dose is increased. 
  • Diarrhea is one of the most common side effects of metformin and can sometimes be severe or persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not commonly associated with diarrhea. Its common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog used as an adjunct treatment for diabetes. It slows gastric emptying and promotes satiety but is not typically associated with diarrhea. Nausea is a more common gastrointestinal side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is not known to cause diarrhea. Hypoglycemia is its most significant side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, metformin is the anti-diabetic drug most commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea. The patient's symptoms are likely related to metformin use.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which protozoan parasite is found within Kupffer cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leishmania donovani

 

  • Kupffer cells are macrophages of Liver.
  • Amastigote form of Leishmania donovani is engulfed by macrophages monocytes, and other reticuloendothelial cells → LD-body
  • LD bodies seen in peripheral smear of a patient with Kala azar

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes

 

Option C. Babesia’s life cycle doesn’t involve liver. Sporozoites directly enter RBCs.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax: In the pre-erythrocytic stage, plasmodium sporozoites invade hepatocytes, where they undergo development into merozoites. Subsequently, these merozoites infiltrate red blood cells (RBCs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The amastigote form of Leishmania donovani, also known as LD bodies, is found within macrophages, including Kupffer cells in the liver, during infection.

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • The clinical image depicts a newborn covered in a shiny membrane that resembles parchment, suggesting a disorder on the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum (Lamellar ichthyosis, Bathing suit ichthyosis, Harlequin ichthyosis)
  • Icthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in the Filaggrin gene (FLG).
  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is unlikely because it does not manifest at birth.

 

Fig: Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, Shedding of collodion membranes after 1 week.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamellar ichthyosis

  • Description: Infants with lamellar ichthyosis are often born with a collodion membrane, which sheds after a few weeks. The skin then becomes darkly pigmented with large, plate-like scales. Ectropion and eclabium can also be present.

 

Option C. Bathing suit ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a rare type of ichthyosis where the scaling is restricted to the trunk, sparing the extremities and face. It's called "bathing suit" due to the distribution pattern resembling the area covered by a bathing suit.

 

Option D. Harlequin ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a severe form of ichthyosis, where infants are born with very thick skin that forms large, diamond-shaped plates separated by deep fissures as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Features like ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory difficulties are common.

 

Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) includes the following:

 

  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI)
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI)
  • Congenital Ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self-limiting congenital ichthyisis (SLCI)
  • Collodion baby

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an unlikely diagnosis in a new-born presenting with a collodion membrane, ectropion, eclabium, and extensive skin lesions, given that ichthyosis vulgaris is typically a milder form and less likely to present with such severe symptoms at birth.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 65 Page no 65.4, 65.6-65.10

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8161842/

questions.text: Which of the following is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontotemporal dementia

 

Frontotemporal dementia, specifically the form associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (FTD-ALS complex), is caused by a hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9ORF72 gene. This expansion consists of GGGGCC (G4C2) repeats. It's one of the few known hexanucleotide repeat disorders and is a significant cause of both frontotemporal dementia and ALS.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fragile X Syndrome: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: Incorrect. There are two types of myotonic dystrophy. Type 1 is a trinucleotide (CTG) repeat disorder, while type 2 is a tetranucleotide (CCTG) repeat disorder.

 

Option D. Huntington disease: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CAG repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene, resulting in an expanded polyglutamine tract.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On USG, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid renal mass that may enhance heterogeneously after contrast administration and generally does not contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: A benign renal tumor that typically appears as a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing mass on imaging, without the characteristic fat component seen in angiomyolipomas.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled, round structure with no enhancement; the lesion in the image is solid with fatty components, inconsistent with a simple cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure
Increase in renal plasma flow
Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Which of the following decreases GFR? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

 

Explanation:

 

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is determined by the balance of pressures acting on the glomerulus. The key pressures involved are the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, which drives filtration, and the oncotic pressure, which opposes it. Additionally, the hydrostatic pressure within Bowman's capsule also opposes filtration.

 

Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: This is the back pressure exerted by the fluid already in Bowman's capsule. If this pressure increases, it opposes the hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries, leading to a decrease in GFR. For example, conditions such as ureteric obstruction can increase this pressure, resulting in reduced GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure: This pressure pushes fluid out of the capillaries and into Bowman's capsule, thus increasing GFR. Therefore, increasing this pressure would not decrease GFR.

 

Option B. Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure: Oncotic pressure is the "holding" pressure due to plasma proteins. A decrease in this pressure would result in less opposition to filtration, thereby increasing GFR, not decreasing it.

 

Option C. Increase in renal plasma flow: An increase in renal plasma flow generally leads to an increase in GFR because more plasma is being filtered through the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure decreases GFR

questions.text: Bleeding gums are seen in which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency in Vitamin C (ascorbic acid). Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, which is crucial for maintaining the integrity of connective tissues, including gums. A deficiency in Vitamin C leads to weakened blood vessels, resulting in symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. The classic symptom of scurvy, bleeding gums, is a direct result of impaired collagen synthesis and capillary fragility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets: Rickets is caused by Vitamin D deficiency, leading to weakened and soft bones. Symptoms include skeletal deformities such as bowed legs and thickened wrists and ankles, but bleeding gums are not a typical feature of rickets.

 

Option C. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease, is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that break easily. It primarily affects bone health and does not typically cause bleeding gums.

 

Option D. Hartnup disorder: Hartnup disorder is a rare genetic condition that impairs the body's ability to absorb certain amino acids from the diet, leading to symptoms like skin rashes and neurological issues. Bleeding gums are not a characteristic symptom of Hartnup disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleeding gums are a classic symptom of scurvy, which is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin C.

questions.text: Which drug is used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by daunorubicin? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexrazoxane

 

Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used specifically to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline chemotherapy agents like daunorubicin. It protects the heart by reducing the formation of free radicals that can damage cardiac tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aprepitant: Aprepitant is utilized to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy. It works as a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist but does not have a role in preventing cardiotoxicity from chemotherapeutic drugs.

 

Option C. Amifostine: Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent that offers protection against the toxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy on normal tissues, particularly for kidneys and salivary glands, but it is not indicated for the prevention of cardiotoxicity from daunorubicin.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. In oncology, it is often used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and to treat certain cancer-related conditions, but it is not used to prevent daunorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexrazoxane is specifically used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by anthracycline chemotherapy agents such as daunorubicin by reducing free radical formation and oxidative stress on the heart.

choices.text: Respiratory rate more than 18 per min
Urine output less than 60 ml in 4 hours

questions.text: A patient of eclampsia is being treated with magnesium sulfate. Which of the following is an indication to stop this drug? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output less than 60 ml in 4 hours

 

Magnesium sulfate is commonly used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. However, it has a narrow therapeutic window, meaning the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small. Therefore, careful monitoring is essential to avoid magnesium toxicity.

 

Key indicators to monitor during magnesium sulfate therapy include:

 

  • Urine output: Magnesium is excreted by the kidneys, so adequate urine output is necessary to prevent accumulation and toxicity. A urine output of less than 100 ml in last 4 hours (or 25 ml/hr) is concerning, but in this question, the threshold given is 60 ml in 4 hours. This reduced output is a sign that the kidneys are not excreting magnesium effectively, indicating a risk for toxicity, and the drug should be stopped.
  • Respiratory rate: Magnesium sulfate can cause respiratory depression. If the respiratory rate drops below 12 breaths per minute, it is a sign of potential magnesium toxicity and an indication to stop the drug.
  • Deep tendon reflexes: Magnesium sulfate can diminish or abolish deep tendon reflexes. The absence of reflexes is one of the first clinical signs of toxicity. Exaggerated reflexes would not be seen with magnesium toxicity; rather, they would be diminished.
  • Cardiac Problems – in late stages

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate more than 18 per min: An increased respiratory rate is not a concern for magnesium toxicity. The concern arises when the respiratory rate is decreased below 12 breaths per minute.

 

Option B. Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes: Magnesium toxicity is associated with diminished or abolished reflexes, not exaggerated ones.

 

Option D. Presence of visual disturbances: Visual disturbances are not typically related to magnesium sulfate toxicity, and thus are not an indication to stop the medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During magnesium sulfate therapy, urine output should be monitored carefully, and a significant reduction in output (less than 60 ml in 4 hours) is an indication to stop the drug to prevent toxicity.

questions.text: In the context of the health belief model, a medical student is reviewing its different components. One of the boxes, labeled "C", is described as the individual's willingness to act on their beliefs regarding health threats and the benefits of taking preventive action. Which of the following best represents box C? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Health motivation

 

  • Box C stands for health motivation.
  • This represents the individual's readiness and willingness to engage in health-promoting behaviors.
  • This motivation influences how individuals perceive their susceptibility and severity of health issues, as well as the benefits and barriers to taking action.

 

 

The health belief model was proposed from the idea that a person's health behaviour changes in accordance with certain beliefs.

 

It can be categorized as follows:

 

  • Individual perceptions.
  • Variable factors that modify beliefs.
  • Action.

 

Individual perceptions:

 

Perceived susceptibility refers to a person's own beliefs about the probability of developing a disease. If the perceived susceptibility is high, an individual is more likely to engage in health-promoting behaviour to reduce the chances of contracting the illness.

 

Perceived severity is an individual's assessment of the severity of a particular health problem. If the disease is perceived to have a high severity, then the person is more likely to adopt a healthier lifestyle. Perceived threat comprises perceived susceptibility and severity. People with a higher perceived threat tend to take on health-promoting activities.

 

Action:

 

Perceived benefits refer to a person's subjective judgment on how a particular health habit is modifying his chances of developing a disease. If the person believes that a habit is likely to reduce his/her chances of susceptibility to a disease or lower the severity of a disease, he/she is more likely to follow that healthy habit.

 

Perceived barriers to action also influence if a person wants to follow healthy behaviour. The benefits of a particular health habit must overweigh the barriers that a person must overcome to continue following that behaviour.

 

Cues to action may be internal or external. Internal cues include pain and clinical symptoms. External cues include awareness through media, physicians, and friends.

 

The health belief system is thought to be useful in analyzing health behaviour patterns and formulating disease prevention plans based on these beliefs. All internal and external factors, including demographic and psychological characteristics, aim at health motivation to attain the action phase of a health belief system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perceived control: Perceived control refers to a person's internal belief in the control they would have over things that are part of the past or the future or over a process, behavior, and outcome. Perceived control can influence all of the categories of the health belief system.

 

Option B. Behavioral modification: Behavioral modification is part of the action after assessing all of the above-mentioned concepts.

 

Option D. Self-efficacy: Self-efficacy can be defined as a person's capacity in achieving his health goals. A person's confidence in his/her ability to overcome limitations to attain his/her health goals was found to be a major factor in determining the outcome of his behavioral changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the health belief model, health motivation (Box C) represents an individual's willingness to act on their health beliefs regarding susceptibility, severity, benefits, and barriers to take preventive health actions.

questions.text: The given arrow corresponds to which level of thoracic vertebra? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fourth and Fifth

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the above image represents the sternal angle (Angle of Louis), which corresponds to the T4-T5 intervertebral disc.

The "angle of Louis," also known as the "sternal angle" or "manubriosternal joint," is an anatomical landmark located in the chest area. The angle of Louis is located at the junction of two important anatomical structures:

 

  • The manubrium of the sternum: This is the uppermost part of the sternum (breastbone) and is shaped like a flat, triangular bone.
  • The body of the sternum: This is the long, flat portion of the sternum that extends downward from the manubrium.

 

Clinical Significance: The angle of Louis is a clinically significant reference point because it corresponds to the level of several important anatomical structures:

It is located at the approximate level of the second rib anteriorly. This makes it useful for counting ribs and identifying rib fractures or landmarks during clinical examinations.

It is also close to the carina of the trachea, which is a critical point in the respiratory system where the trachea divides into the left and right main bronchi.

The angle of Louis serves as a reference for the superior border of the heart and is used in clinical assessments such as cardiac auscultation.Top of Form

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) First and Second Thoracic Vertebrae (T1 and T2): The first thoracic vertebra (T1) is located just below the seventh cervical vertebra (C7). It marks the transition from the cervical spine to the thoracic spine. The second thoracic vertebra (T2) is located just below T1 and continues the thoracic spine.

 

Option B) Second and Third Thoracic Vertebrae (T2 and T3): These vertebrae are adjacent to each other, with T2 immediately below T1 and T3 following T2.

 

Option D) Fifth and sixth Thoracic Vertebrae ( T5 and T6): This option suggests that the arrow corresponds to the region between the fifth and sixth thoracic vertebrae which is lower than the marked arrow in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Sternal angle / Angle of Louis -
    • Between Manubrium & Body of sternum
    • Lies at level of Lower border of T4

questions.text: An accused died in lock up during the police interrogation. Enquiry in this case will be done by? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Judicial magistrate

 

Enquiry in a case of death of police custody/firing will be done by Executive magistrate.

 

Please remember that Custodial death is the only condition where inquest is mandatory to be done only by judicial Magistrate.

 

In India two types of Inquest are held- Police and Magistrate.

 

Magistrate inquest is of further two types- Executive magistrate and judicial Magistrate.

 

Inquest Sections:

 

  1. 174 CrPc: Police Inquest (It is the commonest inquest and Done in all Inquests other than those specified in 176 Crpc)
  2. 176 CrPc: Magistrate Inquest. It is of two types:
  3. Executive Magistrate:  
    • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage 
    • Exhumation. 
  4. Judicial Magistrate: Done in Custodial Deaths

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Executive Magistrate: Handles inquests for dowry deaths and exhumations but not custodial deaths.

 

Option C. Police IG (Inspector General): Does not conduct inquests; senior police officer overseeing police operations.

 

Option D. Head Constable: Can conduct police inquests but not mandated for custodial deaths, which require a Judicial Magistrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of inquest are as follows:

 

 

Ref: KSN Reddy, Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd Ed., p. 132

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylalanine at 508

 

  • Correct. Cystic fibrosis is primarily caused by the deletion of Phenylalanine at position 508 in the CFTR gene. This mutation leads to a malfunctioning CFTR protein, which results in the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tyrosine at position 508. The critical deletion is of Phenylalanine at this position.

 

Option C. Tryptophan at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tryptophan at position 508. The deletion of Phenylalanine at this position is the key mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Lysine at 805: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Lysine at position 805. The F508del mutation is the most common and well-known mutation in cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is due to mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein by deletion of one codon which give rise to phenylalanine at position 508 of this protein. Mnemonic: F-fibrosis, F- Phenylalaine

 

This protein helps in movement of H2O and chloride ion in and out of cell and helps in the formation of mucus secretion and saliva.

 

In normal conditions, the channel allows the formation of thin layer of mucus. But in cystic fibrosis, a thick layer of mucus is formed (see fig) causing airway obstruction leading to infection and ultimately scarring of lung tissue.

questions.text: Which of these disorders was earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

 

Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was earlier referred to as minimal brain dysfunction. ADHD is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder that affects reading, despite normal intelligence. It is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities.

 

Option C. Mental sub normality is an outdated term, previously used to describe intellectual disabilities or developmental delays.

 

Option D. Oligophrenia is an old term that was used to describe intellectual disability or mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADHD, formerly known as minimal brain dysfunction, is characterized by symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity. Diagnosis requires symptoms before age 12 in multiple settings. Treatment commonly involves stimulant medications and behavioral therapy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1171.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is shown in the image below. What other investigations should be done to confirm the diagnosis in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) UGIE + manometry

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario and the barium swallow image show a bird beak sign which indicates achalasia cardia. To confirm the diagnosis, Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and manometry should be performed. Manometry is the IOC for achalasia cardia and other motility disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UGIE + contrast enhanced CT: While useful for structural evaluation, it does not specifically assess esophageal motility.

 

Option B. UGIE + PET: Typically used for oncological assessments, not directly useful for diagnosing motility disorders.

 

Option C. UGIE + 24-hour pH monitoring: Used to diagnose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not directly relevant for achalasia unless GERD is also suspected.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the marked structure? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Internal capsule

 

Explanation:

 

Above marked structure is internal capsule.

 

The internal capsule is a critical white matter structure in the brain. It is located deep within the cerebral hemispheres and separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus. The internal capsule contains axon tracts that serve as major pathways for communication between different parts of the brain, including the cortex, thalamus, and various subcortical nuclei.

 

The internal capsule is often subdivided into three parts: the anterior limb, genu (knee), and posterior limb. Each limb contains different types of nerve fibers that transmit motor, sensory, and other information between the cerebral cortex and other brain regions.

 

The internal capsule consists of several parts and is V-shaped when cut horizontally, in a transverse plane.

 

  • the bend in the V is called the genu
  • the anterior limb or crus anterius is the part in front of the genu, between the head of the caudate nucleus and the lenticular nucleus
  • the posterior limb or crus posterius is the part behind the genu, between the thalamus and lenticular nucleus
  • the retrolenticular portion is caudal to the lenticular nucleus and carries the optic radiation (from medial part of lateral geniculate nucleus) also known as the geniculocalcarine tract. The fiber from lateral part of lateral geniculate nucleus is carried through the retrolenticular portion.
  • the sublenticular portion is beneath the lenticular nucleus and are tracts involved in the auditory pathway from the medial geniculate nucleus to the primary auditory cortex (Brodmann areas 41 and 42)

 

Lesions or damage to the internal capsule can result in various neurological deficits, including motor and sensory impairments.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. External Capsule: The external capsule is another white matter structure located in the brain, but it is less well-known than the internal capsule. It is located lateral to the putamen and globus pallidus and is considered part of the deep gray matter of the basal ganglia. The exact function and significance of the external capsule are still a subject of ongoing research, and its role in brain function is not as well-defined as that of the internal capsule.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe: The caudate lobe, also known as the caudate nucleus, is a part of the basal ganglia. It is a C-shaped structure located within each cerebral hemisphere. The caudate nucleus is involved in various functions, including motor control, cognition, and emotional processing. It is interconnected with other basal ganglia nuclei and plays a role in regulating movement. Lesions or dysfunction in the caudate nucleus can lead to movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease or Huntington's disease.

 

Option D. Globus Pallidus: The globus pallidus is another component of the basal ganglia. It is divided into two segments: the external segment (GPe) and the internal segment (GPi). The globus pallidus is involved in motor control and plays a role in modulating motor signals sent from the cortex to the thalamus. Dysfunctions of the globus pallidus can result in movement disorders, including dystonia and Parkinson's disease.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule's strategic location and structure facilitate critical communication pathways in the brain, making its integrity vital for normal motor and sensory functions. Damage to this area can lead to severe neurological deficits.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

  • To monitor adequacy of neuromuscular blockade ulnar nerve is preferred.
  • It is monitored using a Train of Four monitor/peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle is seen on electrical stimulation of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is frequently used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade during and after anesthesia.
  • It is typically monitored using a device known as a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • The ulnar nerve is accessible and provides a reliable location for monitoring. Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle (a muscle in the thumb) is commonly observed when electrical stimulation is applied to the ulnar nerve.
  • This twitch response is used to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median nerve: While the median nerve can be used for neuromuscular monitoring, the ulnar nerve is more commonly preferred because of its accessibility and ease of stimulation. The adductor pollicis muscle twitch response is typically more reliable for assessing neuromuscular blockade compared to other muscles.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: The radial nerve can also be used for neuromuscular monitoring, but it is not as commonly chosen as the ulnar nerve. Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve offers a more reliable and standard location for monitoring.

 

Option D. Metacarpal nerve: There is no specific nerve called the "metacarpal nerve" commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, typically assessed using a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.

questions.text: What would be the mode of delivery in images 1 and 2? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Image 1: Vaginal; image 2: Cesarean

 

In the provided images, the presentation of the twins is crucial in determining the mode of delivery:

 

  • Image 1: Both twins are in a cephalic presentation (head down), making it safe to consider vaginal delivery. Twin pregnancies where both twins present cephalically are usually managed vaginally unless there are other contraindications.
  • Image 2: The first twin (Twin A or the lowermost baby) is in a breech presentation, while the second twin is cephalic. In this scenario, a cesarean section is preferred to avoid complications associated with breech delivery, such as cord prolapse or head entrapment. Therefore, cesarean delivery is the recommended mode for this presentation.

 

Indications for cesarean in twin pregnancy:

 

  1. First twin is non-cephalic (breech or transverse presentation).
  2. Monochorionic, monoamniotic twins: Elective LSCS at around 34 weeks.
  3. Conjoined twins.
  4. Higher-order multiples (triplets, quadruplets, or more).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In twin pregnancies, the mode of delivery is determined primarily by the presentation of the first twin. If the first twin is cephalic, vaginal delivery can be considered, but if the first twin is non-cephalic (e.g., breech), a cesarean section is generally recommended.

choices.text: Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington's chorea

 

Huntington's chorea is characterized by hyperkinetic movements such as chorea but does not typically present with hypokinetic movements.

 

Huntington's chorea presents with a classic triad of abnormal movements (chorea), dementia, and psychiatric manifestations. It also has a strong family history due to its inherited nature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Parkinson's disease:  Parkinson's disease shows both tremors (hyperkinetic) and bradykinesia (hypokinetic).

 

Option B. Wilson's disease:  Wilson's disease can present with a combination of movement disorders.

 

Option C. Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation:  Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation also shows mixed movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:


Huntington's chorea primarily presents with hyperkinetic movements and not hypokinetic movements.

choices.text: 1 and 3 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
1 and 4 only

questions.text:
Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Ultrasonography
  2. MRI
  3. Angiography
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

 

Explanation:


Ultrasonography and MRI are key modalities used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

  • Ultrasonography (1): This is often the first imaging modality used to diagnose placenta accreta. It helps in visualizing the placental attachment and identifying abnormalities in placental implantation. Color Doppler ultrasonography is particularly useful to assess the blood flow and the vascularity of the placenta, which can indicate abnormal adherence.
  • MRI (2): MRI is used as a complementary imaging tool when ultrasonography results are inconclusive or to provide a more detailed view. It helps in evaluating the depth of placental invasion into the myometrium and can differentiate between placenta accreta, increta, and percreta.
  • Angiography (3): While angiography can provide information about blood vessels and may be used in some cases to evaluate blood flow abnormalities, it is not typically a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta. It may be used in specific scenarios or to plan surgical management, but it is not generally used for initial diagnosis.
  • X-ray (4): X-rays are not used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta due to their lack of sensitivity for soft tissue detail and the potential risk to the fetus. X-rays are not helpful in visualizing the placenta or its adherence to the uterine wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not commonly used for the initial diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

Option C: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta, and it excludes Ultrasonography, which is crucial for diagnosis.

 

Option D: Incorrect because X-ray is not used for diagnosing placenta accreta and does not contribute to the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Ultrasonography and MRI are the primary modalities used for diagnosing placenta accreta.

 

Ref: Page no 1982, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurocysticercosis

 

Explanation:

 

The MRI brain image shows multiple cyst-like lesions within the brain, which are characteristic of neurocysticercosis, often described as a "starry sky" appearance. Neurocysticercosis is an infection caused by the larvae of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium. These lesions are typically cystic with a scolex (head of the larva) visible within the cysts, which is a diagnostic feature. This condition is common in areas where pork is commonly consumed and sanitation practices are poor, and it can lead to serious neurological symptoms like the ones presented by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculoma: Generally appears as well-defined, enhancing masses on MRI, which are not specifically indicated by the cystic nature of the lesions seen in this image.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Common in HIV patients, but typically presents as multiple ring-enhancing lesions rather than the cystic lesions with a clear scolex seen here.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: Typically appear as gelatinous masses in the brain and would not usually present with the clear, cystic appearance with scoleces indicative of parasitic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis should be considered in patients presenting with multiple cystic brain lesions, especially in contexts of headache and altered mental status, where the history and radiological findings suggest the presence of cysts with scoleces typical of tapeworm larvae.

choices.text: ABO incompatibility
Parvovirus B19
Alpha thalassemia major

questions.text: All of the subsequent factors can lead to non-immune hydrops except for: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

Explanation:

 

Non-immune hydrops refers to fetal hydrops that occur due to causes other than those related to maternal-fetal blood group incompatibility. ABO incompatibility is an immune-related cause of hydrops, known as immune hydrops, where the mother's immune system attacks the fetus's red blood cells due to incompatible ABO blood types. Non-immune hydrops arises from various other causes such as cardiovascular issues, genetic disorders, congenital infections, hematologic disorders, placental problems, and miscellaneous conditions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Parvovirus B19: This is a viral infection that can cause non-immune hydrops by affecting the fetus's red blood cells, leading to severe anemia and hydrops.

 

Option C. Chromosomal defect: Chromosomal abnormalities, such as trisomy 21, 18, or 13, can cause non-immune hydrops through associated congenital abnormalities or malformations.

 

Option D. Alpha thalassemia major: This is a hematologic disorder that results in severe anemia, which can lead to non-immune hydrops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABO incompatibility leads to immune hydrops and is not a cause of non-immune hydrops.
